Age of Wonders 4 expands on the foundations of Master of Magic and blends ideas from earlier AoW games, Civilization, and Heroes of Might & Magic 3 to create a uniquely rich fantasy strategy experience. Honestly, AoW4 was a pleasant surprise for me. While Iâ€™ve enjoyed the first two games in the series, the sheer number of society and character customization options in this one left me staring at the screen for a while before even starting my first campaign. Thatâ€™s not a complaint quite the opposite. A game with this much depth shouldnâ€™t limit you to a handful of options. The Tomes, along with the spells they offer, quickly become your best companions throughout the game. Make sure you explore all of them! The in-game systems, innovative mechanics, and the overall atmosphere supported by excellent music and art direction show how much care Triumph Studios put into the experience. One of my favourite additions is the Society Traits system. Itâ€™s not just a simple modifier; itâ€™s a set of mechanics that can deeply affect how other factions interact with you. I wonâ€™t list them all here, but hereâ€™s one piece of advice: make sure the communities you plan to vassalize actually like you.

I also found both the freedom on the campaign map and the tactical depth on the battlefield to be more than satisfying. Even siege battles feel dynamic you can bring in additional siege weapons (or â€œsiege projectiles,â€ as the game calls them) that genuinely change the flow of combat. Another pleasant surprise was the narrative events. Characters act according to their own motives, leading to moments that genuinely caught me off guard like a quest involving a character searching for his lost brother. AoW4 is full of these little surprises.

This game has gradually become my favorite 4X game, and I tend to consider it a modern version of Heroes of Might and Magic. I also highly recommend it to tactical game lovers, as the battle system is based on this format.

For me, the first masterstroke is the creation of a 4X game where you actually finish the game. It's not too long, but above all, the pantheon system will make you want to play through the last few turns even when the outcome of the game is already known.

The second point is the role-playing dimension. I'm more of an optimization-minded person, but I still get caught up in the game because the customization system is so advanced.

The management is rich overall, but accessible. If I understand correctly, compared to other games I love, this one is more accessible and dynamic than Stellaris, without falling into a fake management system like Total War Warhammer (which I also love for its battle system, but whose management is as uninteresting as possible).

Be careful with the economic model, though, as this is a Paradox game. I think that in this case, the value for money is pretty good, and I appreciate having a game that benefits from added content and follow-up, but keep in mind that you may end up paying every year once you get hooked!

Age of Wonders 4 is one of the most rewarding 4X experiences available, blending rich empire building with deep customization and tactical combat that stays exciting hundreds of hours in. What sets it apart is how much love and care the developers pour into it, which shows in every update and expansion. The freedom to shape your own heroes, cultures, and magical identities is unmatched, letting you design anything from noble angelic empires to bizarre beastfolk warbands. That level of control gives the game a refreshing sense of ownership and keeps each run feeling new. The units and cultures themselves play in wonderfully different ways, with unique abilities that make every faction feel distinct on the battlefield. After more than a thousand hours, the charm has not faded. Instead, the replay value keeps growing, and the game continues to feel like a creative playground for fantasy strategy fans.

[h1]Things I Like:[/h1]
[b]+++[/b] The idea of AoW in general: It's kinda like Civilisation with a Dungeons & Dragons skin. I admit, I don't care about the AoW universe and even less about the lore/story because of how standard it is in style compared to Heroes of Might & Magic, Warhammer or LoTR, but I like games where you create your own faction and they give you lots of control and options for play. 
[b]+++[/b] Faction Creation: The biggest selling point for me tbh. In this game they give you many more options in the Faction and Ruler Creator than previous titles. There are more you can apply to your race/units during the game too through spells, for example: It's hard to find a game that lets you do it, but I love the idea of a good guy Necromancer. I created a human faction with Dark/Death culture style, but with Good Alignment trait. There was even the option of a Death Knight class for my ruler! During the game I specialised in Necromancy spells and it was perfect. And to add on to that, later I had the option to cast a spell to modify my race making them all Undead (turning them all ((including my heroes)) into cadavers!) There are still some issues with clothing clipping thru characters with certain bodies (even regular human bodies) that seems to me like there wasn't much effort put into rigging. 
[b]++[/b] You can unlock more options by playing. Faction emblems, ruler customisation items and some faction traits too. I've always said more strategy games need an overall progression system and while it's not that in-depth here, I do appreciate it. 
[b]++[/b] Lots of different units to keep it fresh. You can obtain units outside your starting race too through different events and actions. 
[b]++[/b] Lots of map creation options: Everything from map size and terrain to the types of units you'll find naturally inhabiting the world. 
[b]++[/b] Good art: Some good key art, loading screens art and button art. You can find the artists on Artstation. 
[b]+[/b] Better graphics. Characters look less cartoony. Some animations are low effort but overall an improvement. 
[b]+[/b] Researching spells instead of technologies: It just makes more sense to me than researching what a bow or wheel is for example. We're in a medieval fantasy setting, the world is established right there in the genre so no reason to research things that exist. 

[h1]Things I Dislike:[/h1]
[b]---[/b] Given this Developer's past actions and especially the Publisher's past actions, I simply can't trust them not to do some anti-consumer shit down the line in the never-ending conquest us normies call 'Greed'. I don't like how many overpriced DLC they insist on having every game too. One DLC faction costs half the price of the base game. It's clear their strategy isn't to make a piece of truly special art, but to create a platform to sell off chunks of a game. 
[b]---[/b] It's basically AoE3...but better. And that's the real reason I decided not to buy. I've played a combined 50+ hrs in to AoE3 + AoE:P and after completing one game here, I feel like I've seen everything new they've added. Maybe I'll buy this in a couple years when there's an 'All DLC' edition on the cheap, but I might've moved on by then. These types of games are abundant now. 
[b]--[/b] Army Size still limited to 6 per stack: It gets tedious moving them around the map. 
[b]-[/b] Another of those games where their updates break the Steam Workshop mods and they don't do anything to help or support the modding community but also 'please keep playing our game, buying our DLC and our merch' but also 'we fixed 3 minor bugs that should've been fixed ages ago, so fuck your mods lolololol'. I'm tired of companies being like that.

The presentation is great and flawless in all aspects.
The game is a result of great devotion to the detail!
Personally, I have not met any bugs or crashes at all. 
On the tactical front, I feel I am right in the middle of the action; it is like a blend of Spellforce: Conquest of Eo (3 action points, with a maximum of 2 usable while moving, and the guard mode that prevents flank attacks) and Age of War.

ðŸ§ The unit icons are very appealing, nevertheless, the fighting still appears to be more disordered than in Eo. There are some debuffs whose effects are hard to discern but they do give a more attractive vibe compared to the old Age of War fantasy games. Active abilities are still there for the units, but it's better to say that healing abilities for instance do usually provide "temporary health," meaning they don't restore permanent health but give a boost during the combat that is just temporary. This makes you not to feel as if you are, at the end of a battle, "farming health" and that too as if it was some kind of a feat. So, for now, I might say that even if I find Eo's combat easier or faster, Age of War 4 still has its charm and is therefore enjoyable.

The tier system appears to be more alluring when it comes to basic units; I mean, without a doubt they still have some value. In fact, on some occasions we need to encounter really tough monsters, and the Tier 1 units will still have the role of restraining and grinding them down. Moreover, the difference in terms of damage and especially hit points between Tier 1 and Tier 2 is not that great.
To illustrate, I am totally extrapolating here, but I notice a Tier 5 unit has three times more hit points than a veteran Tier 1 unit!! Nevertheless, it has more area-of-effect powers and, I would say, it can take out five Tier 1 units with minor difficulty, or four Tier 2 units with much greater difficulty and three Tier 3 units on equal ground.

The "context" of the game is improved with a very detailed world creation system: the selection of a world or the creation of your own, together with race, culture, and magic. Besides the selection of a world, one may also pick a ready-made one with different difficulties.
The world creation is itself an extremely enjoyable process. It feels like race is just a "skin"; every race has two basic traits, but you can freely modify them. It's a skin with two exchangeable powers, still, it is stimulating and elaborate, and the powers are found in all soldiers.

The map is magnificently designed, and reducing the level of detail showcases an equally motivating strategic map. 
Armies go along with hexagonal areas; the units can smoothly start the constructing of roads. It costs 3 gold for each road hexagon but he does not ask for maintenance.

The land is divided into "provinces" which are small territories colored with several hexagons of the same environment and decorated with different items. Mice and other animals will also be guarding small treasures. Some of the sites are "wonders" of various ranks (bronze, silver, and gold) that allow you to unlock certain skills when you incorporate them into your cities. The wonders give you new units as well as lots of benefits, but to get them you have to first set them free (by fighting with your hero and their army) and then annex them.

Outposts can be set up by heroes in every province. Settlers (or workers for roads) are no longer required.
Bunkers can be upgraded with essential gold investments that will not only improve their defenses but also allow them to have a small extra annexed province (making them two provinces in total). Besides that, there is a major investment in an empire autonomy resource referred to as "Imperium" to transform them into towns.
The map displays neutral cities of different races (your own race can be among them too), which adds more variety to the diplomatic gameplay. This means that you can make friends with them, do business with them, make them your vassals, and have events happening at times regularly.

In the same way, the diplomacy with the AI appears to be very much alive. The AIs are endowed with characteristics that prescribe their actions. I was able to do commerce with them and even form alliances, and to tell the truth, the AIs were, from an economic point of view, good at playing the game even at the normal level. One of the features of the game is a "Grievance" mechanism (in the case of a diplomatic mistake on your part) which may be converted into trade (meanwhile getting "compensation") or utilized as a justification for war.

Additionally, there is an alignment system simply characterized as Evil/Neutral/Good that transitions with time, but it still appears to be as black and white as portrayed. I am even now unacquainted with the effects of this system on the players. Usually, a tyrant's evilness and the resultant bad stability in their cities do not bring about any problems for them. A good relationship with the neighbors grants the tyrant the reception of diplomacy bonuses with neutral and good allies, but the stability must be positive, which means that the economic bonuses are also the same.

A particular overlord-to-vassal system gives vassals the right to recruit troops, which revitalizes every 15 turns and lets you take units. On top of that, wonders contribute unique soldiers to this pool.

What appears to be absent and comparable to Age of Wonders 3 without mods is the more profound contextualization based on culture. Playtime will confirm or refute this.
The game includes a system that is highly inspired by Warlock 2, where you take over and assign provinces around your city as farms (food), quarries (production) etc. Annexation does not cost anything but needs a population that is ready.

Moreover, in the city, there are gold and production (number of towers) valued structures. All buildings of the first level can be erected, but for the higher levels, the provinces that are compatible are required and the other provinces can also "boost" them, in which case the cost is reduced by one-third. Maintenance costs are no longer applicable for buildings, but still by the time you reach the mid-game, you will have a lot of needs. Besides, the variety of structures is huge and they are well illustrated by the tooltip system.

I absolutely adore Age of Wonders 4. It is perhaps my favorite 4X game of all time. The level of customization is incredible, the gameplay is rewarding, both on a strategic and a tactical level, and it has a high level of replayability. If you're a fan of the 4X genre this is a must have.

It's becoming one of my all-time favorite games, and just makes me want to look up the older AOW titles to play them.

I love being given free reign to create my own fantasy story, and the tools for this keeps expanding each time I return to the game.

You'll either love or hate the strategy and combat of this game. If you need help with tactics or just tips in general, the community is helpful. Outside of multiplayer, every tactic is solid and can be made to work.

The game has two progression systems outside of the actual game. Ascensions, which are a sort of 'soft' newgame+ unlock for your faction you win a game with, which I find fun. Then there's Pantheon levels and unlocks, whose EXP you get from completing a match. The unlocks vary between cosmetics, item variation unlocks for your heroes and new society traits. I find this fun, but it can be slow to progress which some might not enjoy.

The multiplayer is a bit finnicky, I haven't played it lots but it worked the few times I did.

Overall, it's a very good game. 

It looks very nice and it's probably the best 4x fantasy game, at the moment. The DLCs add a lot of new ways to experience the game and what I also like is that the game rewards for actually pushing to victory with the Pantheon system. There's a point system and when you finish a game win or lose you can cash those points into your pantheon and unlock say hero customization, recipes for in game items that you can craft, different mounts for your faction or new culture traits that allow for a different playstyle. And then the game saves your ruler (from a previous game) rewards it with some trait and then you can recruit said ruler into your next game and have even more fun.

At 83 years of age, some games just move too fast for me to play. This one moves at the pace of the players and is very appropriate for senior citizens. However it is taking a good while to wrap my mind around all the details that have to be considered to play effectively. Fortunately I have two sons, avid gamers both, who are tutoring me in the finer points of strategy.

I really enjoyed Age of Wonders 4, especially the incredible amount of options available to customize your race. Being able to shape your faction exactly the way you want adds a lot of personality and replay value to the game. The maps are also a highlight having different options to change the map keeps every playthrough fresh and different. Together, these elements make every new campaign feel unique, and thatâ€™s what makes the game so funÂ andÂ engaging.

If I had to point out a negative thing I would say the clipping in the character creation, there is A LOT of clipping and misplaced hand positions for holding weapons, and helmets that are way too big or too small.

A frustrating and ever-changing game which I can't help but come back to. If you are coming to this with no preconceived notions, an appreciation of the fantastical, and a love of strategy, then you will certainly enjoy this game. However, you should know that the game you buy will not be the game which is available for you to play in 6-12 months time (there's no support of older versions).
 
The trend in the updates is to curtail the variability in the evolution of your characters. For example, I bought AoW in late 2023. At that time, godir and hero characters could fluidly change the weapons they used (ranged, magical, or melee). The upgrades and abilities available to characters were dependent on the research you unlocked.
Now, characters are railroaded into specific classes preventing them from using certain weapon types, because many players disliked that their characters could use other weapons (my brothers, you were equipping the weapon). The abilities available for characters to unlock is now unrelated to your research tree and is restricted based on the class of the character, making research less meaningful and character upgrades less immersive. It also implies that millennia-old wizard kings who practice destructive magic completely bluescreen when handed a sword, which takes me out of the game somewhat.

On the other hand, the variability in the civilisations you can create is vast and has trended upwards, happily, and in general, updates have improved the balance between different cultures.

The inclusion of race transformations which are retained by your godir character into other games are extremely enjoyable goals to pursue in themselves.

Finally, I have to praise the art, design, and worldbuilding. If I praised them to the extent they deserve, 
this review would be far too long. The unit and location models are detailed enough to convey all the information needed, but leave enough ambiguity to fire the imagination. The pop-up lore tabs in particular are a superb detail.

In conclusion, I'm frustrated that this isn't the game I fell in love with, but gladly concede that this is a deeply lovable game.

So I picked this game up via pre-order and honestly hated it come launch day... As someone that loves all the prior AOW games, it took me a while to get this one broken in.  I would have rated it 1 out of 10 stars had you asked me then.... Thankfully I did give it a "third chance" as it is turns out the game is well built and well worth the asking price.  The biggest issues I had (as many others reported) are random in game crashes. My hardware is on the older side (especially my GPU) so the issues I have could be more related to my setup and not the game itself. Not only did the game run sluggishly for me, the in game crashes made it impossible to play even after fixes and updates were rolled out. Here are a few things I would recommend people to do to prevent such crashes if you happen to be running older hardware or have tried everything else and still have issues.

1) If you run multiple displays scale down to just one when playing the game (Trust Me on this)
2) Run the game at 1080p (you have to set your display to 1080p in windows prior to playing)

That's it, nothing more nothing less... Makes 99% of the in game crashes go away as well as the lag. Windows 11 also detected that I was turning my main screen resolution to 1080p while also turning off my second display and created a profile for me, so now I only need to select a single display and it automatically changes my resolution from 4k to 1080p (not sure how windows did this (Co Pilot maybe?) but I am thankful as it limits me to one step!

Once you get the game running smoothly you will find it extremely addictive and very enjoyable.

Feedback for the Devs: 

1) Bring back the pre launch tab game settings like you had with AOW3 and allow users to set a desired in game resolution.

2) Bring back the classic campaign setup in which your Heroes and Items follow you through to the end of the game. Even if you have to change it up a bit like a trigger for previous items to be slowly delivered and/or purchased with-in the armory or maybe a selection option for only a few items that user are prompted to pick prior to starting the next map. I understand the need to keep the game balanced but one of the best things AOW3 had to offer was continuity with Heroes and Items in the campaign mode.

There are a massive amounts of tomes, cultures, lord types, units, spells etc and they keep adding more and more via DLCs. However it all amounts of more of the same in new cosmetic packages. Slight variations of the same formula.

Instead they should have focused on deeper mechanics, such as - 

[list]
[*] Designing your own units mixing and matching cultures, weapons, equipment, technology etc progressively available to your faction. You'd have to observe the challenges you face in a realm, then strategize and refit your armies accordingly.
[*] Heroes should have been designed like actual characters - unique individuals with agency, personalities, voice overs who take part in stories, and in activities beyond just leading armies - be diplomats, spies etc. Instead a hero, even your lord, is basically just another unit, just customizable. It is so lazy and silly that characters do not even have a voice beyond grunting like mutes.
[*] There could have been a court system and in-faction politics based on inter-relation of heroes.
[*] There could have been non-standard scenarios - such as playing as the ruler of a collapsing empire, or a vassal trying to break free from a cruel overlord, or rebuilding civilization in a post-apocalyptic tale. Perhaps there are some added via DLCs. I would not know.
[*] Most of the above really build into one central flaw - lack of story and characters. Whether it is Lord of the Rings, or Dungeons and Dragons, or Game of Thrones - our love of fantasy is deeply rooted in story and characters. The game is utterly lacking in that regard. Without that - all the busywork in the campaigns feel meaningless. If you have played Disciples 2, you would know that story / characters and sandbox in a 4X game are not mutually exclusive.
[*] Pantheon points is an abominable idea, locking lots of content behind massive amount of grind, punishing people who do not have that much free time to play videogames. It is emblematic of the ugly design approach of this game,
[/list]

If you are a fan of Civilization and would like something very similar in the fantasy genre - this is perfect for you. However if you have spend a lot of time playing  previous games in the series, and other games like Total War (especially the Warhammer series), or turn based RPGs like Baldur's Gate series, or Pillars of Eternity or Pathfinder : Wrath of the Righeous etc - you will be disappointed.

Built on a solid formula, but just not that interesting to play. The initial impression of massive diversity in options collapses pretty quickly as you get used to each subcomponent of that diversity: there are 6 different civ types (Feudal, High, Dark, Mystic, Barbarian, Industrial). Each has its own unit roster. Mash that together with one of about 10 races (which just give 3 bonuses each and look different), a choice of spellbook, and a starting hero, and you have a theoretically huge amount of options - but actually you get used to each subcomponent pretty quickly and the factions feel samey as a result. Is there a huge difference between playing an Elf Barbarian versus an Orc Barbarian? One has more ranged damage and the other has more melee damage, but that's about it. Does it massively change your game to pick the lightning book instead of the fire book? Nope, your combat animations look different but you're still swapping some physical damage for elemental damage with an occasional bonus status effect.

In each playthrough, I found myself not thinking about how this game would unfold, but how I'd try it next time with a different race and different settings, because I was already getting bored of the one I was running. Oh, and there was this game-breaking glitch in combat that every time one of my support heroes attacked, it would inflate to fill the whole screen with seizure-inducing flashes and then lock out the turn for about 5 minutes... The champion himself had an animation glitch where he/she/it would raise his weapon, wait for several seconds, and then strike. Then do it again for however many strikes were left. So instead of a quick click-damage attack, each hero attack would take like 20 seconds.

All this amounts almost to 'buy it, try it, and see', except then you have Paradox's DLC addiction to contend with. Either you A) pay hundreds of pounds/dollars/pesetas to pick up every DLC, B) buy some kind of subscription pass so that you don't even own the thing you're paying for, or C) run an undercooked version of the game that's missing half the content and has 'buy this DLC now to play the real game' stickered all over it. I've done this before with EU4, CK2, and Stellaris, and this offering is not remotely worth going through that headache.

This game doesn't have the sauce.

Or if it does, it intentionally hides it from you with the research system. I COULD spend hours looking up wiki articles to see how to get the cool and fun stuff. I COULD spend 100 hours playing until I get to see all the tomes. Or the game could, you know, just show me the good shit so I can get excited about it and choose a path to work towards it right away.

Then there's the combat. In isolation it's fine and fun. However, you're just asked to do way too much of it against too many trash mobs. And auto combat is liable to get one of your units you were trying to rank up killed so congrats, you get to go in and spend 5 minutes manually fighting your hundredth boring trash mob battle of the game. And then when you get to the grand late game battles that you've been preparing for, the unit count is so high that it's just tedious to actually control.

And when the overscoped battles lose your interest, there's nothing that can fill the void. The city building is too shallow to make economic planning interesting. Strategic resources are more of a nice bonus than a hard requirement so you don't need to maneuver for them or deny them from your enemies. And you just kind of have to use the units the circumstances of the game leave you with and then rank them up, again unless you're looking up wiki articles or playing 100 hours to get to the starting line of fun. The overworld quests are shallow and generic. The wonders have mildly interesting vignettes with decent scripted encounters, but that's less than 1% of what you do and you're almost never going to be an appropriate level for the encounter to be a fun challenge.

The Paradox curse of taking a break and realizing you haven't had fun for the last 10 hours continues.
